title: turning normal USB pendrive into a faked bootable USB-CDROM

forumNotes.author: mr_
forumNotes.content:
I found an interesting discussion [http://portableapps.com/node/16594](http://portableapps.com/node/16594 "External link") (about how to abuse an U3 device as bootable USB-CDROM emulator) and a link to a guide how to turn a normal non-U3 pendrive into a one with CD partition perhaps bootable [http://blog.usboffice.kr/?p=146](http://blog.usboffice.kr/?p=146 "External link") (use with care, you can destroy your whole device)  

USBDeview is also an excellent tool if you need some informations so you can find the correct mass production tools.  

Unfortunately the device was neither bootable by USB-CDROM for me and also in DOS I've did try Bart's CD-ROM driver disk and all DOS USB drivers and couldn't find this fakes USB-CDROM, only in Windows seen as faked CD.  

I would like to know if someone had more success then me with booting the faked USB-CDROM.

forumNotes.author: mr_
forumNotes.content:
I wasn't able to boot this faked CD-ROM anywhere.  

But I think there are two different kinds of faked CD-ROM. "Real" faked CD-ROM and "need Windows to exists faked CD-ROM", mine seams the latter.  

The faked CD-ROM is not seen in Linux, neither any DOS CD-ROM driver works and also neither any DOS USB CD-ROM driver works.  

Sounds this plausible?  

> Thanks :smile:, but most of that info needs updating.

> We have more recent info, here, on 911cd and msfn.org.
Well, it's hard to find if you are not in your business so long. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png)  

> Maybe, since you are "wiki willing" I could give you my links and you could put together a wiki page (or add the info to that one) with this info. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png)
You can give it to me and I will see.  

Well, the drdos.org wiki is imho no good software, I prefer mediawiki.  

It's just questionable which wiki to use. drdos.org isn't visited much, neither grub4dos wiki is (and grub4dos related), I think a wiki would be cool on bootland.  

I also don't like wiki because it's "cool", it's practical. In forum old postings are lost after a while and threads blow up with questions and discussions and such, no one is allowed to edit the post of another due to outdated or wrong. In a wiki you have can create a very nice overview of informations but the best reason is the teamwork effect.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> I wasn't able to boot this faked CD-ROM anywhere. > > But I think there are two different kinds of faked CD-ROM. "Real" faked CD-ROM and "need Windows to exists faked CD-ROM", mine seams the latter. > > The faked CD-ROM is not seen in Linux, neither any DOS CD-ROM driver works and also neither any DOS USB CD-ROM driver works. > > Sounds this plausible? Possible, yes. :smile: Plausible, NO. ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) At least on the one stick where I could test the feature, the stick was seen by BIOS as a bootable CD device. It is possible that the problem is simply in the BIOS of your machine(s), like many of the reported problems with USB booting. On the other hand it is VERY plausible ![:(](http://reboot.pro/public/style_emoticons/default/sad.png) that no DOS drivers can detect it, and as well that the particular stick you used has not this feature (and thus it is a "need Windows" one :smile:) However, in order to be bootable, a stick needs NO drivers (DOS, Windows or Linux) it needs to be supported by BIOS. (or by a USB BIOS-like stack, like PLoP). Once the real mode part of the OS (the whole OS for DOS) has booted, THEN an OS specific driver may be needed.

About links, here :smile:: The three "must have" [http://johnson.tmfc....dos/usbdrv.html](http://johnson.tmfc.net/dos/usbdrv.html "External link") [http://vivil.free.fr/usbdosboot/](http://vivil.free.fr/usbdosboot/ "External link") [http://www.georgpotthast.de/usb/](http://www.georgpotthast.de/usb/ "External link") Additional info/ideas/hints: [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=21053](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=21053 "External link") [http://www.boot-land...?...=4260\&st=10](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=4260&st=10 "External link") [http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=20310](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=20310 "External link") [http://www.msfn.org/..._98_t99220.html](http://www.msfn.org/board/Generic_98_USB_d..._98_t99220.html "External link") [http://www.msfn.org/...howtopic=126444](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=126444 "External link") [http://www.msfn.org/...showtopic=46581](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=46581 "External link") [http://www.mdgx.com/files/USBASPI.TXT](http://www.mdgx.com/files/USBASPI.TXT "External link") [http://www.mdgx.com/files/USBASPI.EXE](http://www.mdgx.com/files/USBASPI.EXE "External link") :smile: jaclaz

forumNotes.author: ktp
forumNotes.content:
Fantastic ! I want to report that it works flawlessly for me with a Corsair Voyager GT (8 GB). This device is mentioned as working in the referenced article.  

The BIOS see it as two USB devices of same vendor. When I select the first USB device, it is a fake CD as expected. And under XP, the faked CD is recognized too without problem.  

Next wish list would be to be able to build multiple fake CD on the same key ! This way you can carry on the same key lot of bootable CDs (XP install, Vista install, Linux etc...). A dream that most people would like to get with grub4dos and iso emulation (storing several iso images on the same key and selectively boot them. But we know that this is currently technically impossible since it depends on the iso (real/protected mode switch).  

Edit: well first I think about the iso like XP/Vista or Linux, but it could be a multibootable DVD iso containing bcdw ! So this gives way to lot of possibilities (XP install, BartPE/VistaPE, DOS images...).

forumNotes.author: ktp
forumNotes.content:
Another dream : since the fake CD is possible, why not a fake floppy ? This way on the same USB key we can have a fake floppy, a fake CD and a real USB disk.  

This fake floppy would solve multiple problems, among them installing XP requiring pressing F6 to load additonal drivers, or booting from floppy.  

By the way how can I "imaged" my whole USB key with fake CD? Because all drive image utilities only see the hard disk part of the key, not the fake CD part.

Does anyone know if XP setups accepts also USB FDD for F6 driver disk?

This is like asking "how can I image my HDD and my CD-ROM at the same time? Probable this can not work.

forumNotes.author: ktp
forumNotes.content:
> This is like asking "how can I image my HDD and my CD-ROM at the same time? Probable this can not work.

Let say the USB key has 500 cylinders, and 10 cylinders are used by the fake CD part. I would like to be able to "image" the whole 500 cylinders of the physical USB key.

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
> Let say the USB key has 500 cylinders, and 10 cylinders are used by the fake CD part. I would like to be able to "image" the whole 500 cylinders of the physical USB key.

Once properly configured, what normally is a single device is "presented" to BIOS and OS as a two LUN ones, a CD-like and a HD-like.  

But you are missing a point.  

What you normally see as a hd-like device with (say) a geometry of nx255x63 is ONLY the representation that the controller inside the stick "fakes" when anything (BIOS or OS) interrogates it.  

There is NO actual correspondence between what is seen from the outside and what actually happens inside.  

This apllies as well to the CD-like part.  

It is perfectly possible that the "fake CD" uses a part of the stick that it is at the beginning, at the end or anywhere in the middle as well as several "sequences of blocks" joined together only virtually.  

You should be able to access the LUN corresponding to the CD and backup it's contents, but of course you cannot use on a CD-like device the same tools/methods that you would use on a HD-Like device, most probably a "dd-like" tool like dsfo/dsfi can work at volume level, but cannot say.  

> Does anyone know if XP setups accepts also USB FDD for F6 driver disk?
Yes, sure, with a few little fixes :  
[http://www.boot-land...?showtopic=3431](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=3431 "External link")  
[http://www.msfn.org/...showtopic=82711](http://www.msfn.org/board/index.php?showtopic=82711 "External link")  
but it can also be a "virtual" grub4dos one:  
[http://www.911cd.net...showtopic=20543](http://www.911cd.net/forums//index.php?showtopic=20543 "External link")  

jaclaz

forumNotes.author: was_jaclaz
forumNotes.content:
I am not familiar with that kingston "0951", it is possible: 1) that the particular controller used does NOT provide a "CD-ROM" LUN 2) that the manufacturer's tool needs to be modified to recognize the "0951" or PID Basically the original CHIP manufacturer may use a certain PID/VID and it's manufacturer tool is hardcoded to use that VID/PID, then the manufacturer provides to kingston a tool to change VID/PID and a "kingston custom" manufacturer tool hardcoded to recognize the new PID/VID given by kingston. About chipgenius, you should ***read the whole thread*** , instead of clicking on the first link you find, this one works: [http://www.boot-land...?...c=4661\&st=6](http://www.boot-land.net/forums/index.php?showtopic=4661&st=6 "External link") Use google translate: [http://translate.goo...t...en\&ie=UTF-8](http://translate.google.com/translate?u=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.mydigit.cn%2Fchipgenius.htm&sl=zh-CN&tl=en&ie=UTF-8 "External link") Current version is 2.70, use latest. You will need extensive use of google translate, lots of fantasy, a bit of luck, extensive reading and notwithstanding all these, there is still a risk that you won't be able to find the "right tool" or to use it "properly", there is even a (minor, but possible) risk of simply "messing" with the stick in a way that it won't work anymore.
jaclaz
